title: Naive Economics
description: How mid-twentieth century economics achieved mathematical elegance through optimization models and social welfare functions, but rested on politically naive assumptions about government behavior and human motivation

promptInstructions.focus: You are discussing the period from roughly 1930-1990 when economics was dominated by mathematical optimization models, Social Welfare Functions, and the assumption that government acts as a benevolent social optimizer.
promptInstructions.academicEmphasis: Keep discussions grounded in the appeal of mathematical rigor, the separation of efficiency and equity concerns, and the assumptions about political behavior. Connect to earlier concepts about prestige hierarchies and cultural learning.
promptInstructions.commonMisconceptions: Watch for students either dismissing the mathematical approach entirely or defending it without acknowledging its political assumptions. Help them see both the intellectual appeal and the practical limitations.

breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand how Paul Samuelson's 1947 'Foundations of Economic Analysis' launched the mathematical revolution in economics, driven by physics envy and Defense Department funding

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Today we're looking at what I call "naive economics" - the dominant approach from roughly 1930 to 1990. To understand why it was so appealing, we need to start with 1947, when a young Paul Samuelson published "Foundations of Economic Analysis." The title tells you everything about the ambition.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: "Foundations" sounds pretty presumptuous for a dissertation.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, Samuelson was arguing that economics should be reconceived as the study of mathematical optimization. Consumers optimize their satisfaction, firms optimize their profits, and - here's the key insight - these individual optimizations could be modeled mathematically.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: That's... actually brilliant. Instead of just describing what people do, you can predict it mathematically.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Avery, that's exactly what made it so attractive. Remember, this was the post-war era. Physics had just won the war - radar, atomic weapons, mathematical precision applied to real problems. Economics wanted that same scientific respectability.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: There's precedent for this. Bentham tried to mathematize utility back in the 1780s, and the marginalists in the 1870s—

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: But did it actually work? I mean, for real people?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, that's the question we'll keep coming back to. But first, let's see why this approach became so dominant. MIT's economics department went from nothing in 1940 to dominating the profession by 1960. Why? Defense Department funding. Mathematical optimization seemed perfect for wartime resource allocation.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: So the military funded economics because it looked useful for planning?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Exactly, Blake. And that "economic engineering" mindset spread everywhere - to other universities, to policy institutions, to the Federal Reserve. Finally, economists had clear, mathematical answers to policy questions.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: It must have been exciting. Like economics was finally becoming a real science.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: That's the appeal, Avery. Let's pause here and think about what this meant for how economists saw their role.

breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand how individual optimization by consumers and firms was supposed to lead to Pareto efficiency, and why Blake's critique about inequality being 'optimal' exposes a key problem

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: The mathematical framework rested on a simple but powerful idea: everyone optimizes. You, as a consumer, maximize the utility you get from your choices - how much to work, save, spend. Amazon, as a firm, maximizes the difference between revenue and costs.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: But do people really do calculus when they buy groceries?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, the economists would say it doesn't matter if people consciously calculate. What matters is whether they behave as if they're optimizing. If higher prices lead to less demand, that's consistent with optimization.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: And mathematically, that gives you... what, demand curves? Supply curves?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Right, Avery. But here's where it gets interesting. These individual optimizations, interacting through markets, were supposed to lead to something called Pareto efficiency for the economy as a whole.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: What's that?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, imagine an allocation of resources where no one can be made better off without making someone else worse off. That's Pareto efficient.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: It's named after Vilfredo Pareto, the Italian economist. He was actually more of a sociologist later in life, wrote about elite circulation—

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Wait, hold on. If I own everything and everyone else owns nothing, nobody can be made better off without taking something from me. So that's... Pareto efficient?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, you've hit on exactly the problem with calling it "optimal." That distribution is Pareto efficient, but most people wouldn't call it optimal.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: That's insane. How is massive inequality "efficient"?

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: No, Drew, I think the point is that efficiency and fairness are separate questions. You can have an efficient distribution that's totally unfair.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Avery's got it. This distinction between efficiency and equity became central to the naive economics framework. Let me give you a moment to think about why economists might want to separate these issues.

breakpoints.subheading: Efficiency vs. Equity: The Clean Separation
breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand how naive economics separated efficiency problems (market failures) from equity problems (redistribution), and why this seemed like an elegant solution

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Mainstream economics developed what seemed like an elegant solution to the efficiency-equity problem. Think of it as a two-step process.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: Step one: make the pie as big as possible?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Exactly, Avery. Step one is achieving Pareto efficiency - making sure resources aren't wasted, that every possible mutual gain gets realized. Step two is deciding how to slice the pie - the equity question.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: That's theoretically clean. You solve the efficiency problem through markets, then solve the equity problem through redistribution.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Right, Casey. But markets don't always achieve Pareto efficiency on their own. When they fail - what economists call "market failures" - that's where government steps in with targeted interventions.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: What kind of market failures?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, the classic examples are monopolies, pollution, and what economists call "public goods" - things like national defense where markets tend to under-provide.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: So government fixes the efficiency problems...

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, through specific policies - an antitrust law here, a pollution tax there, a subsidy for basic research. Each intervention targets a specific market failure.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: And then separately, government handles equity through broad redistribution - income taxes, welfare programs, that sort of thing.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Precisely, Avery. The beauty of this framework was that it gave economists clear, distinct roles for government: fix market failures to maximize efficiency, then redistribute to achieve whatever society considers fair.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: But who decides what's fair?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, that brings us to what Arnold Kling calls the "God's-eye view" of the economy. Let's explore that.

breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand the naive assumptions about government motivation and knowledge that underpinned the Social Welfare Function approach

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Naive economics assumed government could take what Kling calls a "God's-eye view" - a perspective that weighs everyone's interests equally and chooses policies to maximize overall social welfare.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: How do you measure "social welfare"?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, through something called a Social Welfare Function. In theory, you could assign weights to different people's utility and add them up to get a single number representing society's well-being.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: That goes back to Bentham's greatest good for the greatest number, doesn't it?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Good connection, Casey. But here's what's crucial: naive economics assumed government would actually want to maximize this social welfare function.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Wait, since when do politicians optimize anything except their own chances of getting reelected?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, that's exactly the kind of question naive economics didn't ask. It simply assumed government would be motivated to act in society's interest.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: But maybe that's not unreasonable? I mean, in a democracy, politicians need to serve voters...

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Avery, that's incredibly naive. Politicians serve the groups that get them elected, not some abstract social welfare function.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: And even if they wanted to maximize welfare, how would they know how? These calculations seem impossibly complex.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, naive economics made a second assumption: that government, with the help of economists, would have the knowledge to implement optimal policies.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: So economists become philosopher-kings, in a sense. Plato would find that ironic.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: But isn't it good that economists were trying to give policy advice based on rigorous analysis rather than just politics?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Avery raises an important point. This framework gave economists a clear professional mission: identify market failures, calculate optimal taxes and subsidies, design redistribution schemes. Let's think about why that was so appealing to the profession.

breakpoints.subheading: The High Status of Economic Engineering
breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand how mathematical economics provided both scientific legitimacy and institutional power to economists, transforming the profession's status

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: By the 1960s, this mathematical approach had transformed economics from a somewhat marginal field into a high-prestige profession. Economists suddenly had definitive answers to policy questions.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: Finally, economics could be as rigorous as physics. You could prove theorems, make precise predictions...

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Right, Avery. And that mathematical rigor translated into real institutional power. The Federal Reserve, the International Monetary Fund, key policy positions - increasingly filled by economists trained in this MIT-style mathematical optimization.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: It's remarkable how quickly it spread. From one department to dominating the entire profession in just two decades.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: But was it actually working? Were these mathematical models giving good policy advice?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, that's where things get complicated. The models were internally consistent and mathematically elegant. Whether they captured the complexity of real economies and real politics... that's a different question.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: It sounds like economists were solving theoretical problems while actual people dealt with the consequences.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, that tension between mathematical elegance and practical relevance became increasingly important. But remember, this approach seemed to offer something economists had never had before: scientific legitimacy and clear social relevance.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: And if the models were wrong, you could always improve them, make them more sophisticated...

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Or you could question whether the whole mathematical approach makes sense for studying human behavior.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake and Avery, you're both touching on debates that would reshape economics. But the engineers believed they could perfect their models, solve social problems through mathematical optimization.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: There's something very twentieth-century about that confidence. The idea that technical expertise could solve political problems.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Exactly, Casey. Let's take a moment to consider whether that confidence was justified.

breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand the emerging critiques of naive economics without fully exploring them - setting up tensions around non-quantifiable factors and political realism

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: By the 1970s and 80s, this elegant framework was facing serious challenges. The critiques came from both left and right, though we'll explore those in detail in later chapters.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: But surely there were obvious problems earlier? I mean, what about power? What about culture? You can't just reduce everything to mathematical optimization.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: Drew, but if you can't quantify something, how can you analyze it systematically? How can you give policy advice?

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: That's exactly the problem! By only looking at what you can measure, you miss the most important things.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: And the whole thing assumes politicians are benevolent social optimizers instead of self-interested power-seekers. That's not naive, it's delusional.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: Now Blake, perhaps the framework could be modified to account for political constraints. The basic mathematical approach might still be sound...

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: No, Casey, it's not just about constraints. It's about power relationships, about who benefits and who loses, about things that can't be captured in equations.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: But Drew, without some kind of systematic framework, you're just... what, telling stories? Making emotional appeals?

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Better honest stories than false precision, Avery.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: I'm willing to be wrong. But let me suggest that both perspectives have merit. The mathematical approach provided unprecedented analytical power. Whether that power was being applied to the right questions, with realistic assumptions about politics and human behavior... those became the crucial debates.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: And meanwhile, real people's lives were being affected by policies based on these unrealistic models.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: But surely some progress was made? Some market failures were identified and corrected?

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Casey, how would you even know if the corrections worked? The whole system assumes you can measure welfare improvements.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Right. Ri-ri-ri-ri-right. These are the tensions that led to what we might call the "post-naive" period in economics. The critiques from the left focused on power relationships and structural inequality that the mathematical models ignored. The critiques from the right questioned whether government actually behaves the way the models assume.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: So the mathematical elegance came at the cost of political realism?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: That's one way to put it, Avery. Naive economics achieved remarkable mathematical sophistication, but its assumptions about politics and human behavior were... well, naive.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: Finally.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: So what happened next? Did economists admit the whole approach was flawed?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, that's what we'll explore in our next chapters. The responses to these critiques fundamentally reshaped economic thinking, though not always in ways you might expect.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: And some economists, I assume, still defend the traditional approach?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Casey, the debates continue. But what's clear is that by 1990, the consensus around naive economics had largely collapsed. Whether what replaced it was an improvement... well, we'll see.
